text: The 2006 Iowa Hawkeyes football team represented the University of Iowa during the 2006 NCAA Division I FBS football season. The Hawkeyes played their home games at Kinnick Stadium and were coached by Kirk Ferentz. After starting the season 5-1, they dropped 6 of 7 games to finish the season with a 6-7 record which included a Big Ten record of 2-6\. ==Schedule== ==Game summaries== ===Montana=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 1–0 | 1954 | W 48–6 |} ===at Syracuse=== *Source: ESPN {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 1–1 | 1976 | W 41–3 |} ===Iowa State=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 35–18 | 2005 | L 3–23 |} In the final in-state match-up of two former Hayden Fry assistant coaches Kirk Ferentz prevailed over Dan McCarney to bring the Cy-Hawk trophy back to Iowa City. A crucial play of the game came in the fourth quarter with Iowa State electing to go for it on fourth down, coming up inches short. ===at Illinois=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 27–37–2 | 2005 | W 35–7 |} ===Ohio State=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 14–43–3 | 2005 | L 6–31 |} ESPN's College GameDay was in Iowa City for this matchup between the #1 Buckeyes (4-0) and #13 Hawkeyes (4-0). After an Albert Young touchdown early in the 2nd quarter brought the Hawkeyes to within 14-10, Ohio State pulled away for the 21-point win. ===Purdue=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 31–44–3 | 2005 | W 34–17 |} The Iowa Hawkeyes welcomed Purdue to Kinnick Stadium one week after losing their much anticipated game against top-ranked Ohio State. Iowa jumped on Purdue early and often, opening up a 14-0 first quarter lead with a touchdown run by Damian Sims and a pass from quarterback Drew Tate to fullback Tom Busch. Kyle Schlicher added two field goals in the second quarter and the Hawkeyes lead 20-3 at halftime. Purdue's only first half scoring came on a 44-yard field goal by freshman Chris Summers. Sims scored again on Iowa's first possession of the second half before Greg Orton caught an 18-yard touchdown pass from Curtis Painter. Tate then hit tight end Scott Chandler for a touchdown and Purdue then responded with a Jaycen Taylor touchdown run. The Boilermakers could get no closer as they were shut out in the fourth quarter. Shonn Greene scored on a short run and Adam Shada returned an interception of a Curtis Painter pass 98 yards for a touchdown. ===at Indiana=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 38–25–4 | 2005 | W 38–21 |} ===at Michigan=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 10–39–4 | 2005 | L 20–23 OT |} ===Northern Illinois=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 5–0 | 1999 | W 24–0 |} ===Northwestern=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 45–19–3 | 2005 | L 27–28 |} ===Wisconsin=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 40–39–2 | 2005 | W 20–10 |} ===at Minnesota=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 39–58–2 | 2005 | W 52–28 |} ===Alamo Bowl=== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" |- align="center" | 1–0 | 1984 | W 55–17 |} ==Team players in the 2007 NFL Draft== {|class="wikitable" width="80%" |- align="center" style="" | Player || Position || Round || Pick || NFL Club |- style="text- align:center;" bgcolor="" | Marshal Yanda || OT||3 || 86 || Baltimore Ravens |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Scott Chandler || TE||4 || 129 || San Diego Chargers |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Mike Elgin || C||6 || 188 || New England Patriots |}2008 NFL Draft Listing Pro-Football- Reference.com ==References== Iowa Category:Iowa Hawkeyes football seasons Hawkeyes football
